results.title: Nintendo Bad Street Brawler videogame
results.brief_description: (mya2Zstore) NES Bad Street Brawler video game (Power glove)
results.description:
Bad Street Brawler (released as Bop-n Rumble in North America and Street Hassle in Europe) was a classic street fighting game made by Melbourne studio Beam Software in 1987. Beam was the first Australian studios to produce games for NES, and Bad Street Brawler has an infamous place in NES history: it was one of just two games ever designed to be used with the Power Glove, a wearable controller with NES buttons along the forearm that could also detect finger movement. Using the Power Glove with the game unlocked extra fighting moves that could be used in the game.

The Power Glove could have been a perfect match for a street fighting game about punching and kicking your way through waves of enemies, but the controller’s slow reaction times, and sensitive calibration, made it unwieldy to use. Ultimately both the game and Glove were poorly received.
description_for_label:

results.title: Clamshell Apple Laptop
results.brief_description: You probably know what this is, but not what it’s called. Technically it’s the Apple iBook G3 but they’re better known as ‘Clamshells’ because of their curved, colourful design. Introduced in the late 1990s, these fashionable laptops reflected early attempts to offer personalisation through its range of vibrant colours, which also made them stand out in film and TV. In Legally Blonde (2001), Reece Witherspoon’s character is seen lining up to buy one and using it later in class. Sure, this is likely product placement, but it reflects how the entry level computer was targeted at the education market. It was also the first mass consumer product to have WiFi built in. We maintain a large collection of this kind of legacy equipment for use in digital archaeology and preservation of early interactive educational products and artworks.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 36]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various recreational activities in the life of the Anderson family, including water skiing, riding speed boats on a lake, a trip to the snow, visiting the Royal Melbourne Show, birthday parties, swimming at a local pool, and a Christmas morning.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 skimming stones at the river
00:01:15:00 picnic lunch, eating sausages in bread
00:03:55:00 an ANSETT plane at a country airport
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a large lake
00:08:25:00 groups of people on the shores of the lake
00:09:46:00 man with binoculars
00:10:24:00 kids eating ice creams
00:11:02:00 sign for ‘Water Ski Spectacular: The Fastest Show on Water’
00:11:18:00 the three boys at a table set with birthday cake and party cups
00:15:04:00 on a speedboat on the lake
00:18:47:00 another birthday party with balloons and cake
00:18:56:00 double-layer sponge cake on a rotating tray (lazy Susan)
00:21:47:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:22:33:00 trip to the snow
00:23:18:00 kids learning to ski
00:25:00:00 siblings in matching outfits holding hands at the Royal Show
00:25:12:00 Showbags stall
00:25:17:00 on the Racing Speedboats ride
00:26:15:00 the Kiddies Ferris Wheel
00:26:25:00 the Merry-Go-Round with the older girls holding the boys on
00:27:08:00 on the Speed Car ride
00:27:57:00 girl with fairy floss in front of the fairy floss stand and then thoroughly enjoying it
00:28:13:00 sign for ‘Delicious Flavoured Milk’
00:29:29:00 the Mad Mouse ride
00:30:00:00 Christmas morning with a pile of presents under the tree and the kids in their pyjamas
00:31:25:00 in the backyard riding new bikes and race car toys
00:33:15:00 playing at the local pool with an inflatable boat
00:37:34:00 a large group of kids lined up for a bike race
00:38:37:00 group of girls on the trampoline
00:39:04:00 cake with a ballerina and ‘Happy Birthday to Denise’ written on top
00:39:28:00 blowing party horns

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 35]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various scenes of life in the Anderson family, including the kids riding a dirt bike, holidays at the beach, and birthday parties.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 family and friends arriving to the house with presents
00:02:03:00 all the kids taking turns on the new Honda dirt bike
00:05:42:00 relaxing at the beach
00:06:12:00 on the dirt bike track
00:08:30:00 riding the dirt bike on the beach
00:10:38:00 couple lounging on the beach
00:11:15:00 teenage girls laughing at the camera
00:12:55:00 boy carrying four ice cream cones dripping on him
00:13:29:00 cricket in the front yard
00:14:01:00 Marie and friends on the beach in stylish sunglasses and bikinis
00:14:24:00 boogie boarding
00:16:49:00 cooking sausages on an open BBQ
00:17:00:00 horse riding on a bush trail
00:19:15:00 kids’ birthday party
00:20:02:00 birthday cake with ‘Happy Birthday Paul’ on top
00:20:08:00 kids’ bike gang
00:20:38:00 musical chairs
00:21:42:00 boy animatedly blowing out candles
00:23:19:00 kids taking turns on the trampoline
00:26:31:00 slow motion trampoline jumping

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film begins with scenes of kids’ birthday parties, horse riding and sports in Ballarat. The family then make a road trip to South Australia, featuring city streets in Adelaide, a visit to an amusement park and a wildlife sanctuary, and more horse riding.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 kids’ athletics day
00:01:16:00 girl dismounting a horse from the back of the saddle
00:02:05:00 horse-riding at an equestrian club
00:07:13:00 a group of kids having fun on a trampoline
00:07:30:00 riding a horse in the backyard
00:08:05:00 kids seated around a table eating cake
00:08:50:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:10:24:00 playing musical chairs
00:12:01:00 kids’ footy (AFL football) match
00:14:01:00 a nun cheering from the sidelines
00:16:05:00 parents watching from the sidelines
00:18:31:00 man riding a horse down a suburban street
00:20:45:00 on a road trip, at the border of South Australia
00:21:59:00 fish and chips on the bonnet of the car
00:23:25:00 busy Adelaide street with Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society building in the background
00:24:09:00 in a department store
00:24:53:00 the kids on a Ferris Wheel and other carnival rides
00:25:50:00 trained seals doing tricks
00:28:00:00 dolphins jumping through rings
00:29:42:00 group family shot at a wildlife sanctuary
00:30:56:00 kids patting a kangaroo
00:32:00:00 kids walking down the steps of an ANSETT plane
00:33:12:00 one of the kids on a tire swing
00:34:18:00 cowboy on a horse
00:34:52:00 paddling around in kayaks on a lake
00:36:23:00 on a boat cruising down the river
00:37:08:00 old steam trains in a yard
00:37:15:00 city streets including trams
00:37:58:00 boys running down train tracks
00:39:01:00 arriving home and pulling suitcases out of the boot of the car

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 kids’ athletics day
00:01:16:00 girl dismounting a horse from the back of the saddle
00:02:05:00 horse-riding at an equestrian club
00:07:13:00 a group of kids having fun on a trampoline
00:07:30:00 riding a horse in the backyard
00:08:05:00 kids seated around a table eating cake
00:08:50:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:10:24:00 playing musical chairs
00:12:01:00 kids’ footy (AFL football) match
00:14:01:00 a nun cheering from the sidelines
00:16:05:00 parents watching from the sidelines
00:18:31:00 man riding a horse down a suburban street
00:20:45:00 on a road trip, at the border of South Australia
00:21:59:00 fish and chips on the bonnet of the car
00:23:25:00 busy Adelaide street with Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society building in the background
00:24:09:00 in a department store
00:24:53:00 the kids on a Ferris Wheel and other carnival rides
00:25:50:00 trained seals doing tricks
00:28:00:00 dolphins jumping through rings
00:29:42:00 group family shot at a wildlife sanctuary
00:30:56:00 kids patting a kangaroo
00:32:00:00 kids walking down the steps of an ANSETT plane
00:33:12:00 one of the kids on a tire swing
00:34:18:00 cowboy on a horse
00:34:52:00 paddling around in kayaks on a lake
00:36:23:00 on a boat cruising down the river
00:37:08:00 old steam trains in a yard
00:37:15:00 city streets including trams
00:37:58:00 boys running down train tracks
00:39:01:00 arriving home and pulling suitcases out of the boot of the car

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various moments in the Anderson family, including kids’ birthday parties, beach holidays and First Communion at the church. There is some great footage of fashion in the 1960s, particularly beach wear.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a birthday party, kids eating cake and wearing paper hats
00:01:08:00 a boy blowing vigorously on a party horn
00:02:00:00 birthday boy receiving his gift, a Tommy Thunder toy machine gun
00:02:33:00 girl with fake vampire teeth
00:03:01:00 people sunbaking on the beach
00:04:03:00 the three boys learning to swim
00:05:47:00 snow or hail on the streets of Ballarat, driving through the storm
00:06:12:00 kids on toy bikes and pushing a dog in a pram
00:07:45:00 rows of children in matching outfits at church
00:08:25:00 learning to ride a bike
00:10:30:00 First Communion at church with all the girls in white dresses and veils
00:11:57:00 an older couple walking down the street
00:13:00:00 boys in party hats
00:13:40:00 birthday cakes and frog in a pond (chocolate frog in jelly)
00:14:45:00 more relaxed sunbaking on the beach
00:15:16:00 the three boys in matching bathers (swimwear)
00:15:47:00 picnic under a large red beach umbrella
00:16:42:00 boy in yellow terry towelling hat enjoying a can of Fanta
00:18:55:00 group of kids exploring on the beach and throwing food to seagulls
00:21:03:00 on the slide at local playground

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows John and Marie on a holiday in Tasmania. They spend time in Hobart, visit New Norfolk and Port Arthur, and finally Launceston.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title cards ‘Holiday in Tasmania’, ‘Produced and Photographed by John R. Anderson’
00:01:30:00 Wrest Point Hotel in Sandy Bay, Hobart
00:02:15:00 views from Mount Wellington, Hobart
00:04:07:00 Franklin Square, Hobart
00:05:00:00 plants and flowers on the road
00:06:10:00 the Bush Hotel in New Norfolk, one of the oldest pubs in Australia
00:07:45:00 driving through the snow
00:09:20:00 visiting the ruins at Port Arthur
00:10:45:00 aerial view of city streets in Hobart including the General Post Office
00:13:47:00 Cataract Gorge Reserve in Launceston
00:15:40:00 city street in Launceston
00:15:55:00 a visit to Entally Historic Home
00:16:28:00 Marie looking stylish with luggage and camera tripod in front of a bus
00:17:25:00 on the boat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows a trip to Adelaide and regional South Australia, including views of the city streets, neon signs, animals, trees and flowers in the countryside, and a horse-drawn tram on the coast, probably at Victor Harbor.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:44:00 aerial view over city streets
00:0:57:00 view of busy street with large ‘Ezy’s’ sign
00:02:34:00 Port Adelaide ship
00:03:41:00 Marie holding a koala
00:04:47:00 neon signs at night
00:06:02:00 in a citrus orchard
00:08:18:00 people on a horse-drawn tram, likely at Victor Harbor
